topic.title: Where are you from?
topic.body: Zeronet isn't regionalÂ¸  and I'd bet we have some visitors from around the globe. I'm personally from the States, but where are you all from?

topic.title: Custom address?
topic.body:
I don't mean .bit addresses. For example, 1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D is for ZeroHello. What tools are available for brute-forcing keys to find addresses that match a pattern? Tor has eschalot (https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/29772/how-do-you-get-a-specific-onion-address-for-your-hidden-service), but what is the 0net equivalent?

ANSWER:
Use VanityGen to generate an address. (I used https://hub.docker.com/r/vanityshed/vanitygen-docker/ because it doesn't build properly on modern systems.) 

Then create a site. In your data directory, rename that site to your public key. Open http://127.0.0.1:43110/yourpublickey, drag open the sidebar once the page loads, enable "This is my site", and finally hit "Sign and publish".

topic.title: arXiv on Zeronet
topic.body:
arXiv.org is a great resource for open-access papers, especially in computer science. It seems like hosting it would be a good match for Zeronet.

Anyone know of an application that automatically scans a webpage for updates and makes a local copy?

For those who hadn't heard of ssb://, here's the blurb from their website:
Scuttlebot is an open source peer-to-peer log store used as a database, identity provider, and messaging system. It features global replication, file-syncronization, and end-to-end encryption.
https://scuttlebot.io/

1517193644_1NGfyDWZU2Y6czRKmXuCTntsf5sbf.body: aloop: how on Earth did you find a mobile-only bank account?

> [alooptheloopthel](#comment_28_1NGfyDWZU2Y6czRKmXuCTntsf5sbf7pX2P): They're very new to the UK https://www.which.co.uk/money/banking/bank-accounts/guides/challenger-and-mobile-banks

Very interesting. They can be more disruptive because they don't have to open physical locations. Plus, most phones are more secure than most computers. Apps are also more phishing resistant... It sounded a little silly at first but now it makes total sense.

1517522636_1BrWfc2d3PZKCUr6mg3brj9GvqVJp.body: OP here... I'm from the east coast of the US, and I mostly just use this because I think the tech is interesting. Same reason I use Tor and follow IPFS and Ethereum.

> [styromaniac](#comment_149_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): That's the beauty of ZeroNet. Nothing here can die.

Death here is just quieter: a 404, 'no peers', etc. I hope zeronet manages to attract some growth, because that would dramatically improve matters.

1517558605_1KNSf9nhRFUc52aeX947CRwWTUGPP.body:
> [styromaniac](#comment_147_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): YouTube is demonetizing channels. Donation model becomes popular. [...]

It seems like the obvious way to do this is to make an interface whereby crypto tokens can be easily given to a content author or provider... or maybe even required for content. Of course piracy would be trivial but a subscription model baked in would be, I believe, beneficial to 0net in the long run.

1514422899_1FzZsDQdh8wk71bDLxURPzmAt2FXe.body: Ditto on the shared list. If there were 'groups' that could be joined, members of the group could vote on content to add it to either a group whitelist or a group blacklist. A user could belong to multiple groups at once, and specify their precedence. For example, there might be a 'clean' group that blocks adult content, but there could be another group dedicated to whitelisting a specific site with adult content.

1517552108_13aB79mzuRLgDYzQthn9wzycjw77W.body: Agreed. Pagination should be the default in order to be scalable. This holds true for 0net as a whole.

1517601475_1BrWfc2d3PZKCUr6mg3brj9GvqVJp.body:
OK I really need to learn how to google. It's in the FAQ:
(https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-create-a-fancy-site-address)
Answer: Use VanityGen (https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=25804.0).

Update: I generated a key but now I can't claim the zite. "Drag the 0 button to the left and use the sidebar to sign your site," the guide says, but when I do, nothing happens. The button moves, but no sidebar appears. What am I doing wrong?

> [gitcenter](#comment_280_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): First generate vanity address, then rename directory of your site to public key, then open http://127.0.0.1:43110/public key, wait for page to open, open sidebar, press This is my site and then Sign and publish.

Thanks. Updated question with the answer. http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Samp7znUg3rurmYkQZkuCdBXFph2BKnX is live.

1519330178_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body: As always, the value of a social network is not in the platform itself, but rather the underlying network of people. In other words a social network is useless without users. That's why highly centralized platforms like Twitter and Facebook dominate, and Diaspora doesn't.

1519339494_1HzyC3255dSGaaj36JAmHcQLTD6A4.body: Tip: always use Tor Browser when using Zeronet over tor. Otherwise you can have side-channel ip leaks, defeating the purpose of using tor in the first place.

1519391319_17EoDsZVVgqN1WCV6uPjtiW8Wjmhw.body:
See http://127.0.0.1:43110/zerosecurity.bit/ for some vulnerabilities and demos. Currently the best practice is to both use Zeronet over Tor, but also to access Zeronet through Tor Browser. (You can do this by modifying the proxy settings to not use proxy for 127.0.0.1 .)

Ultimately such protections are not part of the zeronet architecture. Your browser must protect against scripts and your transport (in this case, tor) must protect against NITs.

The integrity of the content.json is ensured by being signed with the private key corresponding to the public key (site address). As such only sites which allow user content or are run by malicious operators are at risk.

> [kai0](#comment_472_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): I only know we ask server send page or video to us which is very small data but server send page or video to us is big data, and small data hard to block so can use VPN, big mount data easy to block so need go satellite WIFI.

I'm not aware of any satellite providers which provide exclusively downlink. Besides, a VPN only increases latency, a decent one will have more than enough bandwidth.
